Award.AwardTitle: BD Spokes: SPOKE: SOUTH: Large-Scale Medical Informatics for Patient Care Coordination and Engagement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project brings together six universities to design and construct a patient-focused and personalized health system that addresses the fractured nature of healthcare information, and the lack of engagement of individuals in their own healthcare. By taking advantage of the enormous amount of information being created about our environment, through the confluence of real-time, mobile and wearable devices and the availability of rich social media data on patient behavior, the team will create a detailed and comprehensive picture of a patient's health, and a tool to help manage patients' engagement with their health care providers. The system has four key aims to: (1) provide a human-centered approach for integrating electronic health record data generated by traditional methods with data collected "in the wild" (such as personal fitness devices, mobile phone usage, local weather, pollution or even fast food restaurant maps, etc.); (2) develop a framework for deciding which data sources are trustworthy; (3) create a cloud-based system to allow users to view and track their own data over time and improve healthcare outcomes; and (4) provide educational outreach and community participation, particularly in minority populations, to design a system which benefits users in both the short term (through employment and education) and the long term (through increased engagement and trust).

This project will leverage modern distributed cloud-based computing infrastructure (including mobile phones and Amazon Web Services), and the unique capacities of the South BD Hub to house and analyze the enormous volumes of health-related data that are generated every day by people, and their environment. By linking electronic medical records, external databases and data 'in the wild' harvested from patient's Internet-enabled devices, the project will address several issues related to the integration of high-resolution data for longitudinal tracking of patients. These include acceptability of the technology, particularly by vulnerable groups, usability, veracity of data collected, and scalability/integration across a large heterogeneous landscape. By employing patient-centric agile development, the team will work with communities to implement a cloud-based architecture to improve tracking of study participants, increase the ease with which data can be captured, improve patient engagement, and facilitate care coordination. The resultant platform will integrate big data analytics, real time scalable data collection, and social media analytics on patient behavior to analyze cardiovascular disease outcomes among disadvantaged African American and Hispanic patient populations. Additionally, the team will implement data fusion techniques to ensure the veracity of the varying qualities of data collected, and develop machine learning models to identify at-risk patient populations in order to reduce health disparities. Finally, patient engagement and health outcomes will be measured to assess the validity and success of the system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through a series of workshops and co-design sessions, we designed and constructed a patient-focused and personalized health data collection system based on a smartphone app, lined to wearables and electronic health records in order to address the fractured nature of healthcare information, and the lack of engagement of individuals in their own healthcare. Multiple open source software suites were created (under a commercialization friendly license) to allow others to build on this work, aimed not only at data collection, but data processing and developing trust metrics for the wearable and non-traditional behavior data (like phone usage and movement). The system was shown to be privacy preserving, and robust.

Multiple educational outreach and community participation opportunities were generated, particularly in minority populations, to ensure the system was co-designed to benefit users in both the short term (through employment and education) and the long term (through increased engagement and trust). The system was then provided to multiple populations and user participation was analyzed.

Our results indicate that participating patients exhibited significant reductions in the frequency of their weekly outpatient visits during the period of the study (i.e. post recruitment), when compared to the 18-month period prior to study recruitment. Patients also exhibited a significant increase in other useful visits, based on medication refills and procedures, during the study period. While the impact of wearable device use on the incidence of health encounters is associational rather than causal, we can attribute the simultaneous drop in outpatient visits and increase in other visits (during the study period) to an overall change in patient awareness of their health conditions based on their use of the wearable Garmin devices. Specifically, study participants were more likely to use the wearable devices to monitor their health condition, which in turn, is associated with a drop in their overall frequency of outpatient visits, but greater utilization of other healthcare services, such as procedures and prescription refills. In other words, they became more engaged in managing their own healthcare, and felt they needed less attention, with no adverse results.

Our results also provide preliminary evidence of significant associations between patient physiological measures, such as minimum heartbeat rate, active time, maximum stress levels and total sleep time, on the incidence of health encounters. An elevated minimum (resting) heart rate are associated with more frequent hospitalizations, as well as outpatient and telehealth visits. Conversely the average time an individual was active was positively associated with a lower rate of outpatient visits. This result suggests that the amount of time that patients expend in being active is associated with a reduction in outpatient visits. We also observed a positive correlation between Maximum Stress levels and the frequency of telehealth visits, which suggests that patients who experience greater stress are more likely to use telehealth to consult with healthcare providers.

Our results provide preliminary evidence of a link between patients' usage of wearable devices and their engagement with the healthcare system through different types of encounters with healthcare providers.  Overall, our results suggest that patients' physiological measures are weakly correlated with their incidence of health outcomes, although data needs to be collected on a larger scale (both in time and across patients) in a prospective study to confirm these findings.  A control group is also required, that either did not receive the wearable devices, or received a device that reports non-health data, is required, to test if the engagement with the wearable information was the key driver in behavioral change.
